quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces and Friction - Tug of War
quiz.subtitle: Net Force Analysis with Opposing Forces
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: What is the net horizontal force on the box when both Tom and Fred pull?
questions.explanation: Net force $= F_{\text{Tom}} - F_{\text{Fred}} = 80\text{N} - 50\text{N} = 30\text{N}$ in Tom's direction

questions.question: What is the maximum static friction force that must be overcome?
questions.explanation: Maximum static friction $f_{s,\text{max}} = \mu_s N = 0.27 \times (20\text{kg} \times 9.8\text{m/s}^2) = 0.27 \times 196\text{N} = 52.92\text{N} \approx 53\text{N}$

questions.question: Will the box move, and if so, in which direction?
options: Yes, toward Tom because net force $>$ static friction
No, because net force $<$ static friction
questions.explanation: Net force $(30\text{N})$ is less than maximum static friction $(53\text{N})$, so static friction can balance the net force and the box won't move.

questions.question: What is the actual static friction force acting on the box?
questions.explanation: Static friction adjusts to exactly balance the net applied force, so it provides $30\text{N}$ opposing the net force direction (toward Tom).

questions.question: If Tom increases his force to $100\text{N}$, what happens?
options: Box moves toward Tom with $47\text{N}$ net force
Box moves toward Fred with $50\text{N}$ net force
Box moves toward Tom with $100\text{N}$ force
questions.explanation: New net force $= 100\text{N} - 50\text{N} = 50\text{N}$ toward Tom. Since $50\text{N} < 53\text{N}$ (max static friction), the box still won't move! Static friction increases to $50\text{N}$.

questions.question: What minimum force must Tom apply to make the box move toward him?
questions.explanation: Tom needs: $F_{\text{Tom}} - F_{\text{Fred}} > f_{s,\text{max}} \rightarrow F_{\text{Tom}} > 50\text{N} + 53\text{N} = 103\text{N}$

questions.question: If Fred stops pulling, what happens when Tom applies $80\text{N}$?
options: Box moves toward Tom with $27\text{N}$ net force
Box moves toward Tom with $80\text{N}$ force
questions.explanation: With Fred gone, net force $= 80\text{N}$. Since $80\text{N} > 53\text{N}$ (max static friction), box moves. Net force after overcoming friction $= 80\text{N} - 53\text{N} = 27\text{N}$. $a = \frac{27\text{N}}{20\text{kg}} = 1.35\text{m/s}^2$

questions.question: What if both pull with $60\text{N}$ in opposite directions?
questions.explanation: Net force $= 60\text{N} - 60\text{N} = 0\text{N}$. With zero net force, static friction is zero and box remains stationary.

questions.question: If $\mu_s$ increases to $0.35$, what happens with current forces?
questions.explanation: New max static friction $= 0.35 \times 196\text{N} = 68.6\text{N}$. Net force is still $30\text{N}$, which is less than $68.6\text{N}$, so box still doesn't move.

questions.question: What is the normal force on the box?
questions.explanation: Normal force $N = mg = 20\text{kg} \times 9.8\text{m/s}^2 = 196\text{N}$ (assuming horizontal surface)

questions.question: In a tug-of-war, when does the rope move?
options: When net force exceeds maximum static friction
questions.explanation: The rope moves when the net force applied by the teams exceeds the maximum static friction between the ground and the participants' feet.

questions.question: Why can static friction prevent motion even with large opposing forces?
options: It can adjust up to its maximum value
It's always greater than applied forces
questions.explanation: Static friction is self-adjusting - it matches the net applied force up to its maximum value $(\mu_s N)$.

questions.question: What determines the direction of kinetic friction?
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction always opposes the actual direction of motion, regardless of which forces are larger.

questions.question: In a balanced tug-of-war, what is the tension in the rope?
questions.explanation: In a balanced tug-of-war, tension equals the force applied by either team (since they pull with equal force).

questions.question: Why do tug-of-war teams lean backward?
options: To increase normal force and thus friction
questions.explanation: Leaning back increases the normal force between their feet and ground, which increases maximum static friction $(f_{s,\text{max}} = \mu_s N)$, making them harder to pull.

questions.question: What happens to friction if a box is pulled upward at an angle?
options: Friction increases due to more contact
Friction decreases due to reduced normal force
questions.explanation: Pulling upward reduces the normal force $(N = mg - F_{\text{vertical}})$, which reduces the maximum friction force $(f_{s,\text{max}} = \mu_s N)$.

questions.question: In which scenario is static friction zero?
options: Object at rest on frictionless surface
questions.explanation: On a frictionless surface, $\mu_s = 0$, so static friction is zero regardless of applied forces.

questions.question: Why is it easier to keep a box moving than to start it?
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction coefficient $(\mu_k)$ is typically less than static friction coefficient $(\mu_s)$, so less force is needed to maintain motion.

questions.question: What is the role of friction in walking?
questions.explanation: When you push backward on the ground, static friction pushes you forward (action-reaction pair).

questions.question: In a tug-of-war on ice, what determines the winner?
questions.explanation: On low-friction surfaces, the team that can maintain sufficient static friction $(f_s = \mu_s N)$ with the ground will win, as their feet won't slip.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You perfectly understand net force analysis and friction in opposing force scenarios!
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You grasp the concepts but should practice net force calculations with friction.
scoreMessages.50: You're getting there! Focus on how static friction balances net forces up to its maximum.
scoreMessages.0: Review Newton's First Law and how friction responds to net applied forces.
